elements.content: Two isomeric metal–organic frameworks, consisting of Co-triazolate layers and positional isomeric dicarboxylate pillars, both show distinct temperature-dependent CO2 sorption behaviors. Because of the pores functionalized by amino groups, both materials have high CO2 uptake and highly selective sorption of CO2 over CH4 and N2.

elements.content: Two isomeric amine-functionalized metal−organic frameworks constructed from isomeric ligands show distinct temperature-dependent CO2 sorption behaviors and highly selective sorption of CO2 over CH4 and N2.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a novel and fascinating family of porous materials offering promising perspectives for designing tailor-made adsorbents and catalysts. Particularly, MOFs have been extensively studied for selective CO2 capture in recent years due to their advantages such as high porosity, modifiable pore surface, and flexible structures. In general, although large pore MOFs could be effective for storing high capacities of the gas, usually at higher pressures, they may not be as efficient at lower pressures. Similarly, they also would be expected to be less selective in their sorption properties based on pore size alone. In this context, to be a CO2 capture material, the MOFs should have high selectivity and adsorption capacity of CO2 at ambient temperature and lower pressures, as well as the lower cost of synthesis and the stability toward water vapor. Therefore, to enhance CO2 adsorption capacity and selectivity, various strategies have been explored in MOFs construction, including control of pore size, adjustment of surface area and pore volume, and functionalization of MOFs by introducing functional groups and generating exposed framework atoms. Among them, a particularly attractive approach to improve the selective uptake capacity of MOFs toward CO2 is to exploit CO2-triggered framework phase transformations within a dynamic framework, which has been confirmed recently.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a novel and fascinating family of porous materials offering promising perspectives for designing tailor-made adsorbents and catalysts. Particularly, MOFs have been extensively studied for selective CO2 capture in recent years due to their advantages such as high porosity, modifiable pore surface, and flexible structures. In general, although large pore MOFs could be effective for storing high capacities of the gas, usually at higher pressures, they may not be as efficient at lower pressures. Similarly, they also would be expected to be less selective in their sorption properties based on pore size alone. In this context, to be a CO2 capture material, the MOFs should have high selectivity and adsorption capacity of CO2 at ambient temperature and lower pressures, as well as the lower cost of synthesis and the stability toward water vapor. Therefore, to enhance CO2 adsorption capacity and selectivity, various strategies have been explored in MOFs construction, including control of pore size, adjustment of surface area and pore volume, and functionalization of MOFs by introducing functional groups and generating exposed framework atoms. Among them, a particularly attractive approach to improve the selective uptake capacity of MOFs toward CO2 is to exploit CO2-triggered framework phase transformations within a dynamic framework, which has been confirmed recently.

elements.content: Grafting of amines onto the pore surfaces of MOFs not only allows for the increase of polarity but also could adjust the pore size, which has been investigated to augment the CO2 adsorptive affinity and selectivity. For example, Shimizu et al. reported a zinc aminotriazolato oxalate MOF {Zn2(atz)2(ox)} with amine-lined pores, exhibiting very high CO2 uptake and adsorption enthalpy. Subsequently, they used H3PO4 instead of oxalate to construct another MOF, which further affirms that cooperative interactions between CO2 molecules contribute significantly to binding energies. Zhang et al. synthesized three Zn-triazolate dicarboxylate MOFs with high adsorption capacity and selectivity for CO2. In addition, Wang et al. reported two isostructural pillared-layer frameworks with a small pore size based on atz and 1,4-dicarboxylate acid, showing only selective sorption of CO2. Thus, the combination of amino groups into a MOF structure may open an effective approach for the structural design of functional MOF materials for CO2 capture. However, these compounds show rigid frameworks; such a pore pillared-layer framework based on the longer dicarboxylate acid with dynamic structure has been not investigated.

elements.content: Herein, we report two isomeric MOFs, [Co­(atz)­(L)0.5]·DMF (Hatz = 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole, L = 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate (L1) or 3,3′-biphenyldicarboxylate (L2) for 1 and 2, respectively.), which contain naked amino groups and possess the same topology net. Remarkably, compounds 1 and 2 based on positional isomeric biphenyldicarboxylate ligands exhibit distinct temperature-dependent CO2 sorption behaviors.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report two isomeric MOFs, [Co(atz)(L)0.5]⋅DMF (Hatz = 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole, L = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate (L1) or 3,3'-biphenyldicarboxylate (L2) for 1 and 2, respectively.), which contain naked amino groups and possess the same topology net. Remarkably, compounds 1 and 2 based on positional isomeric biphenyldicarboxylate ligands exhibit distinct temperature-dependent CO2 sorption behaviors.

elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Co­(NO3)·6H2O, Hatz, and L1/L2 in a 2:2:1 molar ratio in DMF solvent at 180 °C for 24 h yielded two crystalline products, 1 and 2, respectively. It is interesting that 1 and 2 are supramolecular isomeric frameworks with pillared-layer structures containing Co-triazolate layers and dicarboxylate pillars (Figure ). There is one Co2+ ion, one atz–, half L1/L2, and one DMF molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1/2 (Figure S1, ). The coordination modes of the Co2+ ions, atz–, and L1/L2 ligands are almost the same in 1 and 2. Each Co2+ ion is five-coordinated with two O atoms from one carboxyl group of one individual L1 (or L2) ligand, and three N atoms from three individual atz– ligands. Each atz– ligand binds to three Co2+ ions through 1,2,4-position N atoms, leaving the −NH2 group remain free, and each L1 (or L2) ligand links two Co2+ ions through its two carboxylate ends. Moreover, the atz– ligands link the Co2+ ions into a two-dimensional (2D) Co-triazolate layer, and the resulting layers are further pillared by the L1 (or L2) ligands to generate a three-dimensional (3D) framework which possesses channels. The square aperture diameter for each channel is 4.7 × 4.8 Å2 along the [010] direction for 1 and [101] direction for 2 (excluding van der Waals radii of the atoms) (Figure ). The solvent accessible volumes of 44.7% and 41.4% for 1 and 2, respectively, are calculated. Topologically, both frameworks of 1 and 2 present the same 6-connected pcu network, when considering the Co2 dimers as the 6-connected node.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvothermal reactions of Co(NO3)⋅6H2O, Hatz, and L1/L2 in a 2:2:1 molar ratio in DMF solvent at 180 °C for 24 h yielded two crystalline products, 1 and 2, respectively. It is interesting that 1 and 2 are supramolecular isomeric frameworks with pillared-layer structures containing Co-triazolate layers and dicarboxylate pillars (Figure ). There is one Co2+ ion, one atz-, half L1/L2, and one DMF molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1/2 (Figure S1, ). The coordination modes of the Co2+ ions, atz-, and L1/L2 ligands are almost the same in 1 and 2. Each Co2+ ion is five-coordinated with two O atoms from one carboxyl group of one individual L1 (or L2) ligand, and three N atoms from three individual atz- ligands. Each atz- ligand binds to three Co2+ ions through 1,2,4-position N atoms, leaving the -NH2 group remain free, and each L1 (or L2) ligand links two Co2+ ions through its two carboxylate ends. Moreover, the atz- ligands link the Co2+ ions into a two-dimensional (2D) Co-triazolate layer, and the resulting layers are further pillared by the L1 (or L2) ligands to generate a three-dimensional (3D) framework which possesses channels. The square aperture diameter for each channel is 4.7 × 4.8 Å2 along the [010] direction for 1 and [101] direction for 2 (excluding van der Waals radii of the atoms) (Figure ). The solvent accessible volumes of 44.7% and 41.4% for 1 and 2, respectively, are calculated. Topologically, both frameworks of 1 and 2 present the same 6-connected pcu network, when considering the Co2 dimers as the 6-connected node.

elements.content: The TGA curves of 1 and 2 show obvious weight loss of 22.3 and 21.7% below 185 and 200 °C, corresponding to one DMF per formula unit (calc. 21.8%), respectively (Figure S2, ). Notably, all the DMF molecules in 1 and 2 can be completely removed by soaking the samples in dichloromethane for 48 h and subsequent heating at 60 °C under a vacuum for 6 h, which are verified by TGA analysis. The absence of a CO (DMF) IR band at 1660 and 1672 cm–1 on the desolvated 1 and 2 further demonstrated the removal of DMF from the frameworks (Figure S3, ). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the desolvated samples exhibit high-angle shifting of some peaks, suggesting that both frameworks change upon DMF removal (Figure S4, ). The further variable-temperature XRD measurement also indicates that both frameworks change upon guest removal (Figure S5, ).

The absence of a CO (DMF) IR band at 1660 and 1672 cm-1 on the desolvated 1 and 2 further demonstrated the removal of DMF from the frameworks (Figure S3, ). The further variable-temperature XRD measurement also indicates that both frameworks change upon guest removal (Figure S5, ).

elements.content: To confirm the permanent microporosity of the frameworks, gas-adsorption measurements (N2, H2, CO2, and CH4) of 1 and 2 were performed. The reversible N2 sorption experiments of 1 and 2 at 77 K showed a type I adsorption isotherm behavior (Figure ) with apparent Langmuir surface areas of 902 and 737 m2 g–1, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of 683 and 552 m2 g–1, respectively, and the experimental pore size distribution (PSD) curves based on NLDFT model are shown in Figures S6–S9, . The pore volumes estimated by the Dubinin–Astakhov (DA) method of 0.33 and 0.25 cm3 g–1 for 1 and 2, respectively, compared to the crystallographic pore volumes estimated from their crystal structures were 0.33 and 0.27 cm3 g–1, respectively, which indicates that the filling of N2 in the channels is highly sufficient. The H2 sorption experiments at 77 K exhibited the uptakes of 0.83 and 0.88 wt % at STP for 1 and 2, respectively, which surpass the best zeolite ZSM-5 (0.7 wt %).

elements.content: The CO2 sorption properties on desolvated 1 and 2 at four different temperatures (195, 273, 283, and 293 K) were also investigated (Table ). At 195 K, both compounds show interesting multistep adsorption, but their CO2 isotherms are totally different (Figure ). The CO2 sorption isotherm of 1 at 195 K shows two steps in the adsorption process (Figure a). The adsorption amount is very limited below the pressure P = 0.01 bar, but at that point there is an abrupt increase from 27.6 to 64.3 cm3 g–1 and a further increase to 104.5 cm3 g–1. At P = 0.10 bar, there is another abrupt increase from 104.5 to 175.6 cm3 g–1. Above P = 0.15 bar, the isotherm exhibits a slow increase and then finally attains saturation with the adsorbed CO2 amount of 220.8 cm3 g–1 (43.4 wt % at STP) at 1 bar, corresponding to 2.6 CO2 per formula unit. There is no obvious hysteresis between the desorption and adsorption isotherms of 1 at 195 K. In contrast, large hysteresis is observed in the CO2 sorption isotherms of 2 at 195 K (Figure b). The CO2 adsorption in 2 exhibits two steps. After the first step at P = 0.27 bar, the CO2 uptake reaches 55.5 cm3 g–1. In the second step between P = 0.27–1.0 bar, it reaches 133.1 cm3 g–1 (26.1 wt % at STP), corresponding to 1.5 CO2 per formula unit. The desorption isotherm of 2 also exhibits steps at the corresponding inflection points of the adsorption isotherm but does not trace the adsorption process. The final CO2 uptake value of 2 at 1 bar and 195 K is obviously lower than that of 1, which is also consistent with the lower surface area of 2 than that of 1. Furthermore, at 195 K, the CH4 sorption properties for desolvated 1 and 2 were also investigated (Figure ), and the uptakes of 67.8 cm3 g–1 (4.84 wt %) and 55.8 cm3 g–1 (3.99 wt %) at STP for 1 and 2, respectively, which are much lower than the values of CO2 uptakes at the same condition. Apart from the lower uptakes, similar to the N2 and H2 isotherms, the multistep adsorption also was not observed in the CH4 isotherms of both 1 and 2. The likely reason for the distinct adsorption behaviors should be related to the stronger interaction of CO2 with amino groups in the pores which might increase the phase transition energies and low the pressure required by the phase transformation, and such effects have been studied in a few recent reports.

Selectivity sorption

Once the measure temperatures changed to 273, 283, and 293 K, additional interesting results were observed. For 1, its CO2 isotherms are close to linear (Figure a), and the CO2 uptakes are 75.6 cm3 g–1 (14.9 wt %) at 273 K, 68.0 cm3 g–1 (13.4 wt %) at 283 K, and 59.9 cm3 g–1 (11.8 wt %) at 293 K at 1 bar. For 2, its CO2 isotherms are nonclassical type I adsorption isotherms (Figure b), and the CO2 uptakes are 56.7 cm3 g–1 (11.1 wt %), 49.5 cm3 g–1 (9.7 wt %), and 44.3 cm3 g–1 (8.7 wt %) at 273, 283, and 293 K, respectively. It is obvious that the final CO2 uptake values of 2 at ambient temperature are comparable with 1, while the uptake is much lower than 1 at 195 K. All sorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 293 K for both 1 and 2 did not show large hysteresis.

elements.content: These distinct CO2 sorption behaviors under different temperatures for 1 and 2 may be closely related with their structural features. At low temperature (195 K), the CO2 uptake is mainly dependent on the surface area of each framework. In general, isotherm steps in rigid MOFs can be attributed to sorbate–sorbent interactions as molecules adsorb along the framework surfaces and sorbate–sorbate interactions as they fill the pores. So the likely reason for the first step sorption of 1 and 2 should be the result of amino groups, and the second step is attributed to the expansion of the frameworks. Considering the isomeric biphenyldicarboxylate pillars in the structures of 1 and 2, the distance between adjacent Co-triazolate layers separated by the 3,3′-biphenyldicarboxylate ligands in 2 is shorter than that in 1. Compared to the linear 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate ligand in 1, the “N”-type 3,3′-biphenyldicarboxylate ligand in 2 almost blocked the windows. This might also be the reason for the obvious hysteresis CO2 sorption isotherms of 2 than 1. However, the frameworks flexibility accompanying the rotation of the benzene rings may release these windows at a relative pressure. Although the details of structural changes cannot be identified from a single crystal, the PXRD patterns do help. The PXRD pattern of samples 1 after finishing CO2 adsorption is most consistent with the activated 1, while the pattern of samples 2 is significantly different from the activated 2. These results reveal that the expanded-pore phase of 2 does not change back to the shrunken-pore phase after desorption. Interestingly, both samples of 1 and 2 after the CO2 sorption can return to the initial states by immersion in DMF, and the reintroduced samples were characterized by the PXRD and TGA (see ). Those results further suggest that the frameworks of 1 and 2 are dynamic. Comparison of the known MOFs based on Zn/Co-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillared-layer structures, which possess pcu nets, does not show dynamic features. So the dynamic behavior of 1 and 2 should be attributed to the elongated biphenyldicarboxylate pillars.

elements.content: Another interesting phenomenon is that 2 has comparable CO2 uptake capacity at high temperature with 1. This may be related to the suitable pore size or affinity presented in the structure of 2. The enthalpies of CO2 adsorption for 2 (37.3 kJ mol–1) are much higher than 1 (21.0 kJ mol–1) at zero coverage (Figure ), according to the virial equation from the sorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 293 K (Figure S10, ). Moreover, the amino groups in the structure of 2 are also largely exposed on the porous surface.

elements.content: The selectivities of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 for 1 and 2 were further characterized. The CH4 (273 and 293 K) and N2 (293 K) sorption isotherms were measured (Figure ). Both frameworks display preferential adsorption of CO2 over CH4 (33.9 and 22.8 cm3 g–1 for 1, 41.7 and 19.4 cm3 g–1 for 2 at 273 and 293 K, respectively) and N2 (1.2 cm3 g–1 for 1, 1.5 cm3 g–1 for 2 at 293 K). To evaluate the CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivities of 1 and 2 under mixture gas conditions with single-component isotherms at 293 K, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) can be used to predict multicomponent adsorption behaviors. The predicted adsorption selectivities in 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 with mole ratios of 50:50 as a function of total bulk pressure are shown in Figure ; the calculated CO2/CH4 selectivities of 1 and 2 are 5.4 and 5.2, respectively, which can be compared with some reported MOF materials under similar conditions, such as a highly porous polyhedral MOF (5.6), ZIF-100 (5.9), MOF-177 (4.4), and the hybrid material CNT@Cu3(BTC)2 (5.6). For the mixtures composed of CO2 (15%) and N2 (85%), 1 and 2 exhibit very high initial CO2/N2 selectivities (∼237 for 1 and ∼215 for 2), and the selectivities are 86 and 56 at 1 bar, respectively. The values are comparable to those high selectivities of MOFs functionalized with the open metal sites or polar groups. The significant CO2 sorption selectivity over CH4 and N2 in 1 and 2 can be mainly associated with the differences in the electrostatic interactions between CO2-amine interactions, because of its much larger quadrupole moment (−1.4 × 10–39 Cm2) than CH4 (0 Cm2) and N2 (−4.7 × 10–40 Cm2). In addition, the smaller kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.3 Å) than CH4 (3.8 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å) enables it to easily enter into the pore.

elements.content: In conclusion, by employment of positional isomeric ligands, two isomeric MOFs with amine-functionalized structures were successfully prepared. The substituent groups of the ligands play important role on tuning the structural characteristics and sorption functions. Both of them show distinct temperature-dependent CO2 sorption behaviors and high CO2 selectivities over CH4 and N2. This work presents a good case for comparison of the structure–property differences between isomeric frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, by employment of positional isomeric ligands, two isomeric MOFs with amine-functionalized structures were successfully prepared. The substituent groups of the ligands play important role on tuning the structural characteristics and sorption functions. Both of them show distinct temperature-dependent CO2 sorption behaviors and high CO2 selectivities over CH4 and N2. This work presents a good case for comparison of the structure-property differences between isomeric frameworks.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available and were used without further purification. Infrared spectra (IR) were obtained in KBr discs on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400C elemental analyzer. Thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in nitrogen stream using a Netzsch TG209F3 equipment at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å), and the variable-temperature PXRD patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/MAX-3C diffractometer. All the gas sorption isotherms were measured by using a ASAP 2020M adsorption equipment.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and were used without further purification. Infrared spectra (IR) were obtained in KBr discs on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400C elemental analyzer. Thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in nitrogen stream using a Netzsch TG209F3 equipment at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å), and the variable-temperature PXRD patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/MAX-3C diffractometer. All the gas sorption isotherms were measured by using a ASAP 2020M adsorption equipment.

elements.content: A mixture of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 mmol), Hatz (0.50 mmol), and L1 (0.25 mmol) in DMF (10 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL), heated at 180 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C min–1. The resulting red block crystals of 1 were isolated by washing with DMF and dried in air. The yield was 142.0 mg (84.7%, based on Hatz). Anal. Calcd for C12H14N5O3Co: C, 42.99; H, 4.21; N, 20.89. Found: C, 43.01; H, 3.98; N, 20.85.

The resulting red block crystals of 1 were isolated by washing with DMF and dried in air. The yield was 142.0 mg (84.7%, based on Hatz). Anal. Calcd for C12H14N5O3Co: C, 42.99; H, 4.21; N, 20.89. Synthesis of [Co(atz)(L2)0.5]⋅DMF (2)

The procedure was similar to the preparation of 1, except that the L1 was replaced by L2. The resulting red block crystals of 2 were isolated by washing with DMF and dried in air. The yield was 126.2 mg (75.3%, based on Hatz). Anal. Calcd for C12H14N5O3Co: C, 42.99; H, 4.21; N, 20.89. Found: C, 42.92; H, 4.01; N, 21.13.

elements.content: Diffraction data were collected with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker-AXS SMART CCD area detector diffractometer. Absorption corrections were carried out utilizing SADABS routine. The structure was solved by the direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares refinements based on F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically with the hydrogen atoms added to their geometrically ideal positions and refined isotropically. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Co metal, half L1, and one atz. The reminder of the unit was occupied by extremely electron density, which could be assigned to be DMF molecules. Because there are too many guest solvent molecules in the crystal and they are impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models, the SQUEEZE subroutine of the PLATON software suite was applied to remove the scattering from the highly disordered solvent molecules, and sets of solvent-free diffraction intensities were produced. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinements for both 1 and 2 are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Diffraction data were collected with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker-AXS SMART CCD area detector diffractometer. Absorption corrections were carried out utilizing SADABS routine. The structure was solved by the direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares refinements based on F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically with the hydrogen atoms added to their geometrically ideal positions and refined isotropically. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Co metal, half L1, and one atz. The reminder of the unit was occupied by extremely electron density, which could be assigned to be DMF molecules. Because there are too many guest solvent molecules in the crystal  and they are impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models, the SQUEEZE subroutine of the PLATON software suite was applied to remove the scattering from the highly disordered solvent molecules, and sets of solvent-free diffraction intensities were produced. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinements for both 1 and 2 are summarized in Table .

cln_elements.content:
Solvothermal reactions of Co­(NO3)·6H2O, Hatz, and L1/L2 in a 2:2:1 molar ratio in DMF solvent at 180 °C for 24 h yielded two crystalline products, 1 and 2, respectively. It is interesting that 1 and 2 are supramolecular isomeric frameworks with pillared-layer structures containing Co-triazolate layers and dicarboxylate pillars (Figure ). There is one Co2+ ion, one atz–, half L1/L2, and one DMF molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1/2 (Figure S1, ). The coordination modes of the Co2+ ions, atz–, and L1/L2 ligands are almost the same in 1 and 2. Each Co2+ ion is five-coordinated with two O atoms from one carboxyl group of one individual L1 (or L2) ligand, and three N atoms from three individual atz– ligands. Each atz– ligand binds to three Co2+ ions through 1,2,4-position N atoms, leaving the −NH2 group remain free, and each L1 (or L2) ligand links two Co2+ ions through its two carboxylate ends. Moreover, the atz– ligands link the Co2+ ions into a two-dimensional (2D) Co-triazolate layer, and the resulting layers are further pillared by the L1 (or L2) ligands to generate a three-dimensional (3D) framework which possesses channels. The square aperture diameter for each channel is 4.7 × 4.8 Å2 along the [010] direction for 1 and [101] direction for 2 (excluding van der Waals radii of the atoms) (Figure ). The solvent accessible volumes of 44.7% and 41.4% for 1 and 2, respectively, are calculated. Topologically, both frameworks of 1 and 2 present the same 6-connected pcu network, when considering the Co2 dimers as the 6-connected node.

The TGA curves of 1 and 2 show obvious weight loss of 22.3 and 21.7% below 185 and 200 °C, corresponding to one DMF per formula unit (calc. 21.8%), respectively (Figure S2, ). Notably, all the DMF molecules in 1 and 2 can be completely removed by soaking the samples in dichloromethane for 48 h and subsequent heating at 60 °C under a vacuum for 6 h, which are verified by TGA analysis. The absence of a CO (DMF) IR band at 1660 and 1672 cm–1 on the desolvated 1 and 2 further demonstrated the removal of DMF from the frameworks (Figure S3, ). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the desolvated samples exhibit high-angle shifting of some peaks, suggesting that both frameworks change upon DMF removal (Figure S4, ). The further variable-temperature XRD measurement also indicates that both frameworks change upon guest removal (Figure S5, ).

To confirm the permanent microporosity of the frameworks, gas-adsorption measurements (N2, H2, CO2, and CH4) of 1 and 2 were performed. The reversible N2 sorption experiments of 1 and 2 at 77 K showed a type I adsorption isotherm behavior (Figure ) with apparent Langmuir surface areas of 902 and 737 m2 g–1, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of 683 and 552 m2 g–1, respectively, and the experimental pore size distribution (PSD) curves based on NLDFT model are shown in Figures S6–S9, . The pore volumes estimated by the Dubinin–Astakhov (DA) method of 0.33 and 0.25 cm3 g–1 for 1 and 2, respectively, compared to the crystallographic pore volumes estimated from their crystal structures were 0.33 and 0.27 cm3 g–1, respectively, which indicates that the filling of N2 in the channels is highly sufficient. The H2 sorption experiments at 77 K exhibited the uptakes of 0.83 and 0.88 wt % at STP for 1 and 2, respectively, which surpass the best zeolite ZSM-5 (0.7 wt %).

The CO2 sorption properties on desolvated 1 and 2 at four different temperatures (195, 273, 283, and 293 K) were also investigated (Table ). At 195 K, both compounds show interesting multistep adsorption, but their CO2 isotherms are totally different (Figure ). The CO2 sorption isotherm of 1 at 195 K shows two steps in the adsorption process (Figure a). The adsorption amount is very limited below the pressure P = 0.01 bar, but at that point there is an abrupt increase from 27.6 to 64.3 cm3 g–1 and a further increase to 104.5 cm3 g–1. At P = 0.10 bar, there is another abrupt increase from 104.5 to 175.6 cm3 g–1. Above P = 0.15 bar, the isotherm exhibits a slow increase and then finally attains saturation with the adsorbed CO2 amount of 220.8 cm3 g–1 (43.4 wt % at STP) at 1 bar, corresponding to 2.6 CO2 per formula unit. There is no obvious hysteresis between the desorption and adsorption isotherms of 1 at 195 K. In contrast, large hysteresis is observed in the CO2 sorption isotherms of 2 at 195 K (Figure b). The CO2 adsorption in 2 exhibits two steps. After the first step at P = 0.27 bar, the CO2 uptake reaches 55.5 cm3 g–1. In the second step between P = 0.27–1.0 bar, it reaches 133.1 cm3 g–1 (26.1 wt % at STP), corresponding to 1.5 CO2 per formula unit. The desorption isotherm of 2 also exhibits steps at the corresponding inflection points of the adsorption isotherm but does not trace the adsorption process. The final CO2 uptake value of 2 at 1 bar and 195 K is obviously lower than that of 1, which is also consistent with the lower surface area of 2 than that of 1. Furthermore, at 195 K, the CH4 sorption properties for desolvated 1 and 2 were also investigated (Figure ), and the uptakes of 67.8 cm3 g–1 (4.84 wt %) and 55.8 cm3 g–1 (3.99 wt %) at STP for 1 and 2, respectively, which are much lower than the values of CO2 uptakes at the same condition. Apart from the lower uptakes, similar to the N2 and H2 isotherms, the multistep adsorption also was not observed in the CH4 isotherms of both 1 and 2. The likely reason for the distinct adsorption behaviors should be related to the stronger interaction of CO2 with amino groups in the pores which might increase the phase transition energies and low the pressure required by the phase transformation, and such effects have been studied in a few recent reports.

Once the measure temperatures changed to 273, 283, and 293 K, additional interesting results were observed. For 1, its CO2 isotherms are close to linear (Figure a), and the CO2 uptakes are 75.6 cm3 g–1 (14.9 wt %) at 273 K, 68.0 cm3 g–1 (13.4 wt %) at 283 K, and 59.9 cm3 g–1 (11.8 wt %) at 293 K at 1 bar. For 2, its CO2 isotherms are nonclassical type I adsorption isotherms (Figure b), and the CO2 uptakes are 56.7 cm3 g–1 (11.1 wt %), 49.5 cm3 g–1 (9.7 wt %), and 44.3 cm3 g–1 (8.7 wt %) at 273, 283, and 293 K, respectively. It is obvious that the final CO2 uptake values of 2 at ambient temperature are comparable with 1, while the uptake is much lower than 1 at 195 K. All sorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 293 K for both 1 and 2 did not show large hysteresis.

The selectivities of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 for 1 and 2 were further characterized. The CH4 (273 and 293 K) and N2 (293 K) sorption isotherms were measured (Figure ). Both frameworks display preferential adsorption of CO2 over CH4 (33.9 and 22.8 cm3 g–1 for 1, 41.7 and 19.4 cm3 g–1 for 2 at 273 and 293 K, respectively) and N2 (1.2 cm3 g–1 for 1, 1.5 cm3 g–1 for 2 at 293 K). To evaluate the CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivities of 1 and 2 under mixture gas conditions with single-component isotherms at 293 K, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) can be used to predict multicomponent adsorption behaviors. The predicted adsorption selectivities in 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 with mole ratios of 50:50 as a function of total bulk pressure are shown in Figure ; the calculated CO2/CH4 selectivities of 1 and 2 are 5.4 and 5.2, respectively, which can be compared with some reported MOF materials under similar conditions, such as a highly porous polyhedral MOF (5.6), ZIF-100 (5.9), MOF-177 (4.4), and the hybrid material CNT@Cu3(BTC)2 (5.6). For the mixtures composed of CO2 (15%) and N2 (85%), 1 and 2 exhibit very high initial CO2/N2 selectivities (∼237 for 1 and ∼215 for 2), and the selectivities are 86 and 56 at 1 bar, respectively. The values are comparable to those high selectivities of MOFs functionalized with the open metal sites or polar groups. The significant CO2 sorption selectivity over CH4 and N2 in 1 and 2 can be mainly associated with the differences in the electrostatic interactions between CO2-amine interactions, because of its much larger quadrupole moment (−1.4 × 10–39 Cm2) than CH4 (0 Cm2) and N2 (−4.7 × 10–40 Cm2). In addition, the smaller kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.3 Å) than CH4 (3.8 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å) enables it to easily enter into the pore.

Furthermore, at 195 K, the CH4 sorption properties for desolvated 1 and 2 were also investigated (Figure ), and the uptakes of 67.8 cm3 g-1 (4.84 wt %) and 55.8 cm3 g-1 (3.99 wt %) at STP for 1 and 2, respectively, which are much lower than the values of CO2 uptakes at the same condition. Apart from the lower uptakes, similar to the N2 and H2 isotherms, the multistep adsorption also was not observed in the CH4 isotherms of both 1 and 2. The likely reason for the distinct adsorption behaviors should be related to the stronger interaction of CO2 with amino groups in the pores which might increase the phase transition energies and low the pressure required by the phase transformation, and such effects have been studied in a few recent reports. 

Once the measure temperatures changed to 273, 283, and 293 K, additional interesting results were observed. For 1, its CO2 isotherms are close to linear (Figure a), and the CO2 uptakes are 75.6 cm3 g-1 (14.9 wt %) at 273 K, 68.0 cm3 g-1 (13.4 wt %) at 283 K, and 59.9 cm3 g-1 (11.8 wt %) at 293 K at 1 bar. For 2, its CO2 isotherms are nonclassical type I adsorption isotherms (Figure b), and the CO2 uptakes are 56.7 cm3 g-1 (11.1 wt %), 49.5 cm3 g-1 (9.7 wt %), and 44.3 cm3 g-1 (8.7 wt %) at 273, 283, and 293 K, respectively. It is obvious that the final CO2 uptake values of 2 at ambient temperature are comparable with 1, while the uptake is much lower than 1 at 195 K. All sorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 293 K for both 1 and 2 did not show large hysteresis.

The selectivities of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 for 1 and 2 were further characterized. The CH4 (273 and 293 K) and N2 (293 K) sorption isotherms were measured (Figure ). Both frameworks display preferential adsorption of CO2 over CH4 (33.9 and 22.8 cm3 g-1 for 1, 41.7 and 19.4 cm3 g-1 for 2 at 273 and 293 K, respectively) and N2 (1.2 cm3 g-1 for 1, 1.5 cm3 g-1 for 2 at 293 K). To evaluate the CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivities of 1 and 2 under mixture gas conditions with single-component isotherms at 293 K, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) can be used to predict multicomponent adsorption behaviors. The predicted adsorption selectivities in 1 and 2 for CO2/CH4 with mole ratios of 50:50 as a function of total bulk pressure are shown in Figure ; the calculated CO2/CH4 selectivities of 1 and 2 are 5.4 and 5.2, respectively, which can be compared with some reported MOF materials under similar conditions, such as a highly porous polyhedral MOF (5.6), ZIF-100 (5.9), MOF-177 (4.4), and the hybrid material CNT@Cu3(BTC)2 (5.6). For the mixtures composed of CO2 (15%) and N2 (85%), 1 and 2 exhibit very high initial CO2/N2 selectivities (~237 for 1 and ~215 for 2), and the selectivities are 86 and 56 at 1 bar, respectively. The values are comparable to those high selectivities of MOFs functionalized with the open metal sites or polar groups. The significant CO2 sorption selectivity over CH4 and N2 in 1 and 2 can be mainly associated with the differences in the electrostatic interactions between CO2-amine interactions, because of its much larger quadrupole moment (-1.4 × 10-39 Cm2) than CH4 (0 Cm2) and N2 (-4.7 × 10-40 Cm2). In addition, the smaller kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.3 Å) than CH4 (3.8 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å) enables it to easily enter into the pore.
